description: From Middle English trillen, from Italian trillo, trillare. Compare Norwegian trille, Swedish trilla.

entries.meaning: (music) A rapid alternation between an indicated note and the one above it, in musical notation usually indicated with the letters tr written above the staff.
(phonetics) A type of consonantal sound that is produced by vibrations of the tongue against the place of articulation: for example, Spanish ⟨rr⟩, /r/.
A tremulous high-pitched vocal sound produced by cats.

verbs.description: trill (third-person singular simple present trills, present participle trilling, simple past and past participle trilled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To create a trill sound; to utter trills or a trill; to play or sing in tremulous vibrations of sound; to have a trembling sound; to quaver.
(transitive) To impart the quality of a trill to; to utter as, or with, a trill.
examples: to trill a note, or the letter r

description: Perhaps identical to Etymology 3, but compare the same sense of drill, and German trillen, drillen.

verbs.description: trill (third-person singular simple present trills, present participle trilling, simple past and past participle trilled)

examples: Whisper'd sounds / Of waters, trilling from the riven stone.

description: Probably related to Old English þweran (“to twirl, stir”).  Compare twirl, thirl, and Swedish trilla, Norwegian trille, etc.

verbs.description: trill (third-person singular simple present trills, present participle trilling, simple past and past participle trilled)

description: Perhaps a blend of true +‎ real.
